title: Documentation for tf.train.init_from_checkpoint doesn't say what it does when
body_html:
Base on the code, tf.train.init_from_checkpoint seems to overwrite the initializers of variables to load from the given checkpoint. The actual initialization will then occur when tf.global_variables_initializer() or similar is executed.

However, the documentation makes no mention of this. It's written as if the initialization happens now. I suppose it does happen now for eager mode, but for Graph mode the initialization is delayed.

This is particularly confusing in a TPU context where code is executing in all sorts of places, so it took me a while reading through the underlying source code before I understood what was going on.
body_text:
Base on the code, tf.train.init_from_checkpoint seems to overwrite the initializers of variables to load from the given checkpoint.  The actual initialization will then occur when tf.global_variables_initializer() or similar is executed.
However, the documentation makes no mention of this.  It's written as if the initialization happens now.  I suppose it does happen now for eager mode, but for Graph mode the initialization is delayed.
This is particularly confusing in a TPU context where code is executing in all sorts of places, so it took me a while reading through the underlying source code before I understood what was going on.
body:
Base on the code, [`tf.train.init_from_checkpoint`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/train/init_from_checkpoint) seems to overwrite the initializers of variables to load from the given checkpoint.  The actual initialization will then occur when `tf.global_variables_initializer()` or similar is executed.

However, the documentation makes no mention of this.  It's written as if the initialization happens *now*.  I suppose it does happen now for eager mode, but for Graph mode the initialization is delayed.

This is particularly confusing in a TPU context where code is executing in all sorts of places, so it took me a while reading through the underlying source code before I understood what was going on.
